Award.AwardTitle: STEM EduGators: UF Noyce Scholars Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Phase I project establishes the STEM EduGators to increase the quantity and quality of STEM majors who enter the teaching profession. A total of fifty $10,000 scholarships for undergraduate students entering the final student teaching experience and ninety $4950 summer internships are being awarded. The Program is expanding opportunities for 10 undergraduates per year who need financial assistance as they continue their major in a mathematics or science discipline while acquiring a minor in education. The Noyce Summer Internship Program provides 18 STEM EduGators with job opportunities in informal science education settings. Project partners include the University of Florida's College of Liberal Arts and Sciences and College of Education, the Alachua County school district, and the PK Yonge Development Research School. The project, using formative and summative assessment as well as an external evaluator, is tracking the Noyce scholars to determine outcomes of bringing STEM majors into teaching. The project includes research on and support for Noyce Scholars as they enter the teaching profession.

The Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program operates as a component of the University of Florida UFTeach program. During their first four years of full-time teaching, the Noyce Scholars are expected to impact and enhance learning for approximately 18,000 students. The first cohorts of UFTeach students recruited from fall 2009 through spring 2011 indicate that the program is significantly increasing the number and diversity of STEM majors going into teaching. Over the five-year duration of funding ninety informal science education internships are being awarded. Each intern is reaching out to hundreds of school children and citizens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The STEM EduGators Noyce Program aimed to meet Florida's need for new and creative strategies that addressed enduring critical teacher shortage areas as well as improved the quality of new educators entering the workforce. The STEM EduGators Noyce Program accomplished this through the recruiting, training, and retaining of a diverse group of academically talented STEM majors to become secondary mathematics and science teachers with the knowledge and skills necessary to make an impact in high-need school districts. Qualified participants were Noyce Scholars, receiving a $10,000 scholarship. Another group of participants were Noyce Interns, receiving a $4,950 summer stipend to learn/teach in an informal education setting.

The project, using both formative and summative assessment, tracked the Noyce Scholars to determine outcomes of recruiting STEM majors into teaching. 

The STEM EduGators Noyce Program operated as a component of the University of Florida UFTeach program. In addition to need qualifications, to select the STEM EduGators Noyce Program awardees, both for scholarships and internships, the UFTeach co-directors considered teaching potential, academic ability, underrepresented status in the discipline, and developing subject area knowledge of each applicant.

Scholarships 

Scholarships were awarded to high achieving students entering their final year, to support them financially when they served as apprentice teachers. The lower than anticipated number of scholarships awarded was the result of fewer academically eligible students meeting the financial need requirements of the program. Over the course of the five-year grant, 36 EduGator Noyce Scholars received support based on their academic performance and financial need.

Demographic Patterns:

  • Of the total of 36 scholarships awarded, 7 were given in Year 1; 5 in Year 2; 1 in Year 3; 6 in Year 4; 5 in Year 5; and 12 in Year 6 (no cost extension). Of the 36, 26 are currently teaching.
  • 27 of the awardees were females (75%) and 9 (25%) were males. 
  • Age group was predominantly between 21 and 23
  • Average GPA was 3.53
  • Students belonged to 10 different majors; Mathematics (61%), Biology (11%); Science Education (8.3%); Religion, Food Science & Human Nutrition, Math Education, Chemistry, Geology, Wild Life Ecology and Physics (2.7% each).

Internships

In addition to the scholarships, over the five-year (plus no-cost extension year) duration of the grant, 102 students participated in an Informal STEM education (ISE) summer internship. These internships helped retain Noyce participants in the teaching career path as well as taught them the importance of ISE in students' overall learning. There was no financial need requirement for this award. Students were placed in a variety of settings including a natural history museum, aquarium, zoological park, botanical park, nature center, and children's museum, located in Florida and in other cities across the nation.  

Some of the institutions in which Noyce Interns completed internship experiences included the following:

  • Florida Museum of Natural History in Gainesville
  • Golisano Children's Museum of Naples
  • Jacksonville Zoo and Gardens
  • Miami Science Museum
  • Mote Marine Laboratory and Aquarium in Sarasota
  • The Florida Aquarium in Tampa
  • Cade Museum in Gainesville
  • Witte Museum in San Antonio, Texas
  • Paleo Research Institute in New York
  • Pacific Science Center in Seattle
  • Museum of Discovery and Science in Ft. Lauderdale
  • Mayborn Planetarium at Central Texas College
  • MIT Museum in Boston

 

Each Noyce Intern effectively reached out to hundreds of school children and citizens during the course of their summer internship. All students began the program with a stated belief in the importance of ISE. However, it is clear from the post internship surveys that they in fact had a different and deeper appreciation for ISE settings. The pre-posttest asked about the experiences and their effect on students' decisions to stay in the teaching career. A strong positive impact on the decision to stay in teaching and especially in understanding how STEM learning can occur in informal settings occurred.

Benefits reported by the internship awardees included:

  • Increased interest in the field and commitment to teaching
  • Better tools for teaching; acquisition of new skills
  • Deciding factor in choosing teaching as a career
  • Understanding and appreciating the importance of learning science in informal settings
  • Knowledge and availability of resources/peer support

Students were asked about what obstacles a teacher faced when incorporating ISE into their classrooms.  Frequent pretest responses focused on cost, the availability of appropriate locations, and time. Post internship responses additionally listed curriculum requirements, assessment, and need for careful organization as obstacles. Overall the program met its goal of reinforcing/deepening participants' understanding of the importance of ISE.

Dissemination of findings:

The features and implications of the programs were disseminated to the broader community through postings on the university's website, on the Noyce website; and presented at national meetings of STEM EduGators Noyce Program Principal Investigators, during mathematics and science education conferences (both regionally and nationally), with local and state press releases, and through articles published in peer-reviewed journals.
